greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Numbers of the form p^2 + q^2, with p and q primes.
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Index entries for sequences related to sums of squares
example: 18 belongs to the sequence because it can be written as 3^2 + 3^2.
mathematica: q=13; imax=Prime[q]^2; Select[Union[Flatten[Table[Prime[x]^2+Prime[y]^2, {x,q}, {y,x}]]], #<=imax&] (* _Vladimir Joseph Stephan Orlovsky_, Apr 20 2011 *)
program: (PARI) list(lim)=my(p1=vector(primepi(sqrt(lim-4)),i,prime(i)^2), t, p2=List()); for(i=1,#p1, for(j=i,#p1, t=p1[i]+p1[j];if(t>lim, break, listput(p2,t)))); vecsort(Vec(p2),,8) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jun 21 2012
xref: A214723 is a subsequence. Complement: A214879.
Cf. A214511 (least number having n orderless representations as p^2 + q^2).
results.author: _Felice Russo_
